text: yarmouk the refugee camp for
Palestinians that's now a symbol of
suffering it's been besieged by
government forces for nearly a year and
torn by the fight against rebel groups
on this day there's a moment of calm and
agreement to allow students out but just
for two weeks at schools across Syria
hold final tests it's been a walk
through a war zone we heard gunfire just
before their journey started students
going to sit their exams may seem a
simple thing but here in Yarmouk it took
weeks of negotiations days of delay and
huge security concerns that's what life
is like when you live under siege on our
last visit to yarmouk we saw how
desperate conditions are thousands of
families trapped inside depend on food
aid but they're only getting a quarter
of what they need to survive because the
situation is so volatile
no wonder there's such relief when the
students finally emerged upmann who
stuck outside yarmouk hasn't seen his
daughter Laila for ten months he tells
me my happiness is so big there was a
lot of galore I can spread it around the
world you're feeling really happy thank
you or thank you buses organized by the
UN's agency for Palestinian refugees
take the students away they call the
parents they left behind and try to
remember the streets they haven't seen
for months when we arrived at the
schools which now serve as shelters
there are more tearful reunions we are
hoping you know that you know your mood
will be opened you know it's not to get
a permission or not I permission but to
have a small you know movement of people
in and out so that we can feel that he
can they have the choice you know
anything but exams aren't the only thing
on the minds of students who've escaped
from a living hell ya gonna calm a bit
dark on we have to eat food that no one
can eat grass spices life is very
difficult inside you can't understand it
until you live there I was outside the
house and when I came home I found a
rocket had landed my mother and my two
sisters were killed my other two sisters
are injured it's not a life but we say
thank God Gansler book do you learn
every day we went to school we put our
hand on our heart because so many people
have died but we insisted we had to go
to school of course we were scared but
we had to continue if we lose our future
no one can help us
it's straight to revision for their
exams they know how much they matter
barcelo nah but when they're over its
back to yarmouk where their lives their
future is not in their hands least to
set BBC News Damascus
